content:
The "Deficit Reduction Act of 2003" and the "Irrigation Subsidy Reduction Act of 2001" are two Acts with short titles. The first Act focuses on reforming the Bureau of Reclamation water pricing, while the second Act aims to reduce irrigation subsidies. Congress acknowledges the long-standing Federal reclamation program's significant impact on western States' water resources. The program, in existence for over 90 years with a substantial taxpayer investment, provides irrigation water to meet increasing demands. However, the original intent to support small family farms has been hindered by inadequate subsidy implementation, leading to excessive water use encouraged by below-cost prices. (5) Below-cost water prices in the arid West encourage excessive water use, while reasonable price increases for wealthy farmers could promote water conservation. (6) The Federal Government has started using income-based eligibility tests for entitlement and subsidy programs, aligning with the historic approach of limiting water subsidies to smaller farms in the reclamation program. (7) Implementing a means test based on gross income in the reclamation program would enhance the achievement of family farm goals outlined in Federal reclamation laws. SEC. 103. AMENDMENTS. The Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 is amended to redefine legal entity and operator in relation to farm operations. Legal entity now includes various entities that own, lease, or operate a farm for multiple individuals. The term operator is clarified as an individual or entity that manages a farm operation. The term 'operator' refers to an individual or legal entity managing a farm operation on land owned or leased by others under any agreement. This definition includes employees and legal entities that are controlled by or have control over another legal entity. The term 'single farm operation' refers to the total acreage of land served with irrigation water for which an individual or legal entity is the operator. The term 'single farm operation' pertains to the total acreage of land irrigated by an individual or legal entity, with rules in place to determine if separate parcels are operated as a single farm operation. Labor and equipment sharing activities do not automatically indicate a single farm operation, and the performance of certain services is also considered. The Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 is amended to clarify that agricultural activities such as chemical application, pruning, or harvesting on a parcel of land do not automatically indicate that the farm operation is part of a single farm operation on other parcels of land. The Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 is amended to clarify that agricultural activities on a parcel of land do not automatically indicate that the farm operation is part of a single farm operation on other parcels of land. The Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 is amended to specify that the Secretary shall identify a single individual or legal entity as the owner, lessee, or operator for each parcel of land receiving irrigation water. If no single individual or entity can be identified, those with equal decision-making and supervision responsibilities will be considered jointly as the owner, lessee, or operator. The Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 is amended to include provisions for single farm operations generating over $500,000 in gross farm income. All parcels of land owned, leased, or operated by an individual or legal entity will be considered part of a single farm operation if the gross farm income exceeds $500,000. The Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 now includes provisions for single farm operations with gross farm income exceeding $500,000. Irrigation water can be provided at less than full cost to a number of acres based on the income reported by the recipient in the most recent taxable year. The Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 includes provisions for single farm operations with gross farm income exceeding $500,000. The $500,000 amount for taxable years after 2002 is adjusted for inflation based on the GDP implicit price deflator. The inflation adjustment factor is calculated annually by the Secretary. Section 206 of the Act is amended to include certification of compliance. The Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 includes provisions for single farm operations with gross farm income exceeding $500,000, adjusted for inflation. Section 206 of the Act is amended to include certification of compliance. The Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 requires owners, lessees, or operators in districts with irrigation water contracts to provide a certificate of compliance, including details on land ownership, leases, and fees reflecting the value of irrigation water. The Secretary may request documentation such as leases for examination. The Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 mandates owners, lessees, or operators in irrigation districts to submit a certificate of compliance with details on land ownership, leases, and fees related to irrigation water value. Section 214 regarding trusts is repealed, and administrative provisions include amendments to penalties under Section 224(c) for regulations, data collection, and penalties enforcement. The Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 mandates penalties for non-compliance and updates interest rates for underpayments. Reporting requirements are amended to include "operator or contracting entity," and sections are redesignated in the Memorandum of Understanding. The Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 updates penalties for non-compliance and interest rates for underpayments. Sections are redesignated in the Memorandum of Understanding, with sections 229 and 230 becoming sections 230 and 231, and a new section 228 is inserted. The Secretary, Secretary of the Treasury, and Secretary of Agriculture will create a memorandum of understanding to allow the Secretary access to information from the Treasury and Agriculture departments for enforcing Federal reclamation law. The Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences is terminated, with corresponding amendments to Title 10 of the United States Code. The termination will take effect after the graduation of the last enrolled class, while the amendments will be effective upon the enactment of the Act. The provisions of chapter 104 of title 10, United States Code, will continue to apply to the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences until its termination under this Act. TITLE III--TERMINATION OF PRODUCTION UNDER THE D5 SUBMARINE-LAUNCHED MISSILE PROGRAM

The Secretary of Defense will terminate production of D5 submarine-launched ballistic missiles under the program. Funds may only be used for termination costs. SEC. 302 of the legislation allows for the continued production and maintenance of D5 submarine-launched ballistic missiles, ensuring funds are available for these activities.
